18 I. INTRODUCTION
19 Plaintiffsโ Second Amended Complaint (โSACโ) seeks injunctive relief and
20 monetary damages for allegedly unconstitutional strip search procedures at
21 defendantsโ Century Regional Detention Facility (โCRDFโ) in Lynwood,
22 California.  (Dkt. 109.)  Plaintiffs move for certification of an injunctive relief
23 class under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2) of all โpresent or future
24 women inmates of the LA County Jail who, upon their admission or return to
25 CRDF from outside of CRDF, are being or will be strip/visual body cavity
26 searched in a group, with other inmates, in an outside bus stall.โ  Plaintiffs also
27 request certification of a similarly defined damages class under Rule 23(b)(3) of
28 all women who have been subjected to this strip-search procedure.

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 2 of 34   Page ID #:4714
1 II. LEGAL STANDARD
2 โ[A]n essential prerequisite of an action under Rule 23 is that there must be
3 a โclassโ.โ  Charles Alan Wright, Arthur R. Miller & Mary Kay Kane, Federal
4 Practice and Procedure  ยง 1760, at 134 (3d ed. 2005).  โA class definition should
5 be precise, objective, and presently ascertainable.โ  OโConnor v. Boeing N. Am.,
6 Inc., 184 F.R.D. 311, 319 (C.D. Cal. 1998) (citation and internal quotation marks
7 omitted); accord Keegan v. Am. Honda Motor Co., Inc., 284 F.R.D. 504 (C.D. Cal.
8 2012).  However, โthe class does not have to be so ascertainable that every
9 member can be identified at the commencement of the action.โ  Wright, Miller &
10 Kane ยง 1760, at 136.  Rather, โ[i]f the general outlines of the membership of the
11 class are determinable at the outset of the litigation, a class will be deemed to
12 exist.โ  Id. at 136-37.  A class is โsufficiently defined and ascertainable if it is
13 administratively feasible for the court to determine whether a particular individual
14 is a member.โ  Keegan, 284 F.R.D. at 521 (citation and internal quotation marks
15 omitted).
16 To obtain certification of their proposed classes, plaintiffs bear the burden
17 of establishing each of the four requirements of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure
18 23(a), together with at least one of the requirements of Rule 23(b).  Ellis v. Costco
19 Wholesale Corp., 657 F.3d 970, 979-80 (9th Cir. 2011).
20 The four Rule 23(a) requirements are numerosity, commonality, typicality,
21 and adequacy, i.e., (1) the class is so large that joinder of all the members under
22 Rule 19 is impracticable; (2) there are one or more questions of law or fact
23 common to the class; (3) the named partiesโ claims are typical of the class; and (4)
24 the class representatives will fairly and adequately protect the interests of other
25 members of the class.  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(a); Ellis, 657 F.3d at 980.  The Court
26 must perform โa rigorous analysis [to ensure] that the prerequisites of Rule 23(a)
27 have been satisfied.โ  Wal-Mart Stores v. Dukes, 131 S. Ct. 2541, 2551 (2011)
28 (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).  The plaintiff must prove that the
2

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 3 of 34   Page ID #:4715
1 proposed class presents common questions of law or fact.  Id. at 2550-51.  In other
2 words, the class membersโ claims โmust depend upon a common contention . . . of
3 such a nature that it is capable of classwide resolution โ which means that
4 determination of its truth or falsity will resolve an issue that is central to the
5 validity of each one of the claims in one stroke.โ  Id. at 2551.
6 Plaintiffs seek certification of an injunctive relief class and a damages class. 
7 An action for classwide injunctive relief is authorized by Rule 23(b)(2) if โthe
8 party opposing the class has acted or refused to act on grounds that apply
9 generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory
10 relief is appropriate respecting the class as a whole.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(2). 
11 Certification of a subsection (b)(2) class โis appropriate only where the primary
12 relief sought is declaratory or injunctive.โ  Zinser v. Accufix Research Inst., Inc.,
13 253 F.3d 1180, 1195 (9th Cir. 2001), amended by 273 F.3d 1266 (9th Cir. 2001). 
14 Certification of a damages class under subsection (b)(3) requires a different
15 analysis.  The plaintiffs must establish that (1) โquestions of law or fact common
16 to class members predominate over any questions affecting only individual
17 members,โ and (2) โa class action is superior to other available methods for fairly
18 and efficiently adjudicating the controversy.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 23(b)(3).
19 III. DISCUSSION
20 A. Class Definition
21 Plaintiffs propose a damages class of โwomen in the custody of LA County
22 Jail who, upon their admission or return to CRDF from outside of CRDF, until the
23 time the practice stops or a date set for the verdict cutoff in this case, were
24 strip/visual body cavity searched in a group, with other inmates, in an outside bus
25 stall.โ  (Dkt 193 at 2.)  They propose a similarly defined class for the injunctive
26 relief claim.  These are clearly defined and readily ascertainable classes.  It is
27 undisputed that membership in the damages class can be determined from CRDF
28 prison records.  Cf. Keegan, 284 F.R.D. at 521-22 (class was ascertainable where
3

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 4 of 34   Page ID #:4716
1 membership could be verified by readily available documentation).
2 B. Rule 23(a) Requirements
3 Plaintiffs have the burden of demonstrating that their proposed classes meet
4 Rule 23(a)โs four requirements of numerosity, commonality, typicality, and
5 adequacy.  Zinser, 253 F.3d at 1186.  Defendants do not dispute numerosity.  They
6 dispute the adequacy of the named plaintiffs to represent the proposed injunctive
7 class, but do not dispute the adequacy of the proposed representatives of the
8 damages class.  Defendantsโ main argument against certifying both classes is that
9 plaintiffs have not demonstrated that there is a โcommon question of law or factโ
10 sufficient to satisfy Rule 23(a)โs commonality and typicality requirements.
11 1. Commonality & Typicality
12 Plaintiffs assert that the common question of law or fact in this case is
13 โwhether Defendants had a custom, pattern and practice of routinely strip
14 searching inmates returning from outside the jail under unconstitutional
15 conditions.โ  (Dkt 207:  Reply at 12.)  However, โit is insufficient to merely allege
16 any common question . . . .โ Ellis, 657 F.3d at 981; Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2251
17 (โ[A]ny competently crafted class complaint literally raises common questions.โ)
18 (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).  The concept of โunconstitutional
19 conditionsโ potentially encompasses many disparate conditions.  โThus stated, the
20 common question is too broad.โ  Parsons v. Ryan, 289 F.R.D. 513, 516 (D. Ariz.
21 2013) (class of all Arizona prisoners receiving medical care proposed common
22 question to be โwhether Defendants are deliberately indifferent to their health and
23 safety in violation of the Eighth Amendmentโ).
24 Wal-Mart established that simply formulating a common question is not
25 enough to satisfy Rule 23(a).  Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2251.  Instead,
26 โ[c]ommonality requires the plaintiff to demonstrate that the class members have
27 suffered the same injury.โ  Id. (emphasis added, citation and internal quotation
28 marks omitted).  The fact that the class members may have โall suffered a violation
4

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 5 of 34   Page ID #:4717
1 of the same provision of lawโ โ such as the Fourth Amendment right to be free of
2 unreasonable searches or the Eighth Amendment right to be free from cruel or
3 unusual punishments โ does not necessarily mean that all the class membersโ
4 claims โdepend upon a common contention . . . of such a nature that it is capable
5 of classwide resolution . . . .โ  Id.  Different strip searches could violate the Fourth
6 Amendment in different ways.  Cf. id. at 2551 (Title VII โcan be violated in many
7 ways . . . [so] the mere claim by employees of the same company that they have
8 suffered a Title VII injury . . . gives no cause to believe that all their claims can
9 productively be litigated at once.โ).  Nevertheless, not all questions of fact and law
10 must be common to satisfy Rule 23(a)(2).  Hanlon v. Chrysler Corp., 150 F.3d
11 1011, 1019 (9th Cir. 1998).  โThe existence of shared legal issues with divergent
12 factual predicates is sufficient, as is a common core of salient facts coupled with
13 disparate legal remedies within the class.โ  Id.(emphasis added); accord Meyer v.
14 Portfolio Recovery Assocs, 707 F.3d 1036, 1041-42 (9th Cir. 2012) (reiterating
15 Hanlon in light of Wal-Mart), cert. denied, 133 S. Ct. 2361 (2013).
16 Wal-Mart makes clear, however, that whatever divergent factual predicates
17 may underlie individual class membersโ claims must be sufficiently similar that
18 โ[t]he common contention must be โcapable of classwide resolution โ which
19 means that determination of its truth or falsity will resolve an issue that is central
20 to the validity of each one of the claims in one stroke.โโ  Meyer, 707 F.3d at 1041-
21 42 (quoting Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2551).  โWhat matters to class certification is
22 not the raising of common questions โ even in droves โ but, rather the capacity
23 of a classwide proceeding to generate common answers apt to drive the resolution
24 of the litigation.โ  Wang v. Chinese Daily News, Inc., 737 F.3d 538, 543 (9th Cir.
25 2013) (quoting Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2251).  Accordingly, when considering a
26 motion for class certification, the Court must โโdetermine whether there was a
27 common pattern and practice that could affect the class as a whole.โโ Id. at 544
28 (quoting Ellis, 657 F.3d at 983).  In the present case, that question is whether the
5

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 6 of 34   Page ID #:4718
1 conditions experienced by all the class members during the strip searches were
2 substantially the same, so that the issue of the constitutionality of these conditions
3 can be resolved โin one stroke.โ  Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2551.
4 Assessing commonality frequently requires an examination of the merits of
5 a plaintiffโs claims.  Id, at 2551-52; Ellis, 657 F.3d at 981-82.  Here, the issue of
6 commonality and typicality overlaps with plaintiffsโ claims about the manner in
7 which new or returning inmates were strip searched at CRDF.  Wal-Mart
8 described two ways in which a plaintiff might be able to establish that her own
9 injury from a defendantโs behavior is shared by โโa class of persons who have
10 suffered the same injury.โโ  Wal-Mart, 131 S. Ct. at 2553 (quoting General Tel.
11 Co. of Sw. v. Falcon, 457 U.S. 147, 157-58 (1982)).  First, if the defendant
12 routinely applied a particular procedure to every potential class member, then the
13 legality of that procedure would present a common question under Rule 23(a). 
14 Second, in the absence of a routine procedure, a plaintiff can establish
15 commonality by presenting โsignificant proofโ that the defendant behaved in
16 accordance with a โgeneral policyโ that was illegal.  Id.  Regardless of the method
17 of proof employed, โ[i]f there is no evidence that the entire class was subject to the
18 same allegedly [unlawful practice or policy], there is no question common to the
19 class.โ  Ellis, 657 F.3d at 983.
20 As described below, there is substantial evidence that all strip searches as
21 CRDF are conducted according to a standard procedure under conditions that in
22 many respects are the same for all inmates, while at the same time there are
23 numerous variations in individual inmatesโ experiences of being strip searched. 
24 Thus, commonality has been established as to some of the conditions that plaintiffs
25 claim contribute to the unconstitutionality of the manner in which the strip
26 searches are performed, but it has not been established as to all of the purportedly
27 relevant conditions.
28
6

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 7 of 34   Page ID #:4719
1 (a) Common Conditions During Strip Searches
2 Many aspects of the strip search are undisputed.  Women who enter and exit
3 CRDF are strip searched in Bus Bay 3, at least when the temperature in the area is
4 above 68 degrees Fahrenheit.  Buses carrying inmates enter the bay through a
5 metal garage door that is rolled down while the searches are performed.  However,
6 the wall opposite this garage door is shared with CRDFโs reception center; a large
7 mechanical door provides access between Bus Bay 3 and the reception center. 
8 During strip searches, this door often remains open, blocked only by large laundry
9 carts.  Instead of a roof, the top of the bay is a chain link fence that is currently
10 covered by a tarp.  One side of the bay is cinderblock; the other side is currently
11 partially covered by wood panels (which extend high enough to block the view
12 from the adjacent bus bay), with tarps hanging above these panels that cover a
13 portion of the side of the bay.  The floor is porous gray cement.
14 There is also little dispute about the strip search procedure.  The women are
15 strip-searched in groups of up to sixty people.  They are not permitted to speak
16 during the searches unless instructed to.  They are told not to look in any direction
17 except forward.  At the beginning of each strip search, a group of fully clothed
18 inmates is escorted in a straight line into Bus Bay 3 and told to stand with their left
19 shoulders against the cinderblock wall.  They are then told to face the wall, and
20 stand โshoulder to shoulder.โ1  Inmates are instructed to place any personal
21 belongings that they have on their person โ e.g., court papers and toiletries โ in
22 their hands behind their backs.  Deputies then search this property for contraband
23 and place it on the floor behind each inmate.  Inmates are then instructed to
24 remove their outer garments โ shoes, socks, pants, and shirts โ and hold them
25
26
1  Defendants argue that, under Los Angeles Sheriffโs Department (LASD) policy,
27 the inmates are required to stand with space between them so that their shoulders do
not touch.  Plaintiffs have submitted declarations stating that inmates often stand
28
close enough to touch shoulders or hips. 
7

Case 2:10-cv-01649-SVW-JEM   Document 232   Filed 03/12/14   Page 8 of 34   Page ID #:4720
1 behind their backs.  Deputies search these items for contraband and place them on
2 the ground behind each inmate with her personal property.  Inmates are then told
3 to lift the back of their hair, so that deputies can see their hair and neckline.
4 Inmates are then told to turn around towards the deputies and run their
5 fingers along the bands of their underwear and bras.  Inmates with large folds of
6 skin or large breasts are told to lift them so that deputies can confirm that no
7 contraband is tucked underneath.  Inmates are also told to open their mouths and
8 roll their tongues around so that deputies can confirm that there is no contraband
9 inside.  At this point, inmates are told to turn back towards the wall, facing away
10 from the deputies.  They are instructed to lower their underwear to their knees. 
11 They are then required to bend over and look back through their legs, spread their
12 body openings, and cough, so that each deputy can visually inspect their body
13 cavities.  Next, they are ordered to reach behind their bodies and use their hands to
14 spread apart their buttocks and their labia.  After each inmate is inspected, she is
15 told to get dressed, gather her belongings, and stand in line with her shoulder to
16 the wall while waiting to be escorted into CRDF. 
17 The women are instructed to line up on both sides of Bus Bay 3, so that
18 while facing the interior, they are in plain view of each other.  Moreover, when
19 they are told to bend over and look through their legs and manipulate their

6 2. Adequacy of Representatives for Injunctive Relief Class
7 Defendants argue that a Rule 23(b)(2) class cannot be certified because the
8 proposed representative plaintiffs for this class (Barranca, Vigil, and Paiz) lack
9 standing to pursue injunctive relief.  It is undisputed that these three plaintiffs
10 were housed in CRDF at the time plaintiffs moved to amend the complaint to add
11 their claims for injunctive relief, a motion that was granted.  (See Dkts 43, 51, 56.)
12 Defendants argue, however, that because they are no longer housed at CRDF, they
13 face no imminent threat of future injury from the allegedly unconstitutional search
14 procedures, and so lack Article III standing.  This argument is foreclosed by
15 County of Riverside v. McLaughlin, 500 U.S. 44 (1992).  The Court must
16 determine โwhether the elements of Article III standing . . . were satisfied at the
17 time the complaint was filed.โ  Haro v. Sebelius, __ F.3d __, 2014 WL 21353, at
18 *6 (9th Cir. Jan. 2, 2014) (citing McLaughlin, 500 U.S. at 51).  When the first
19 amended complaint was filed, โplaintiffsโ injury was at that moment capable of
20 being redressed through injunctive relief.โ  McLaughlin, 500 U.S. at 51.  โ[T]hat
21 the claims of the named plaintiffs have since been rendered mootโ does not
22 deprive the Court of jurisdiction, and does not render the proposed representatives
23 of the injunctive relief class inadequate.  Id. at 51-52; Pitts v. Terrible Herbst, Inc.,
24 653 F.3d 1081, 1092 (9th Cir. 2011) (โ[I]f the district court certifies the class,
25 certification relates back to the filing of the complaint.  Once the class has been
26 certified, the case may continue despite full satisfaction of the named plaintiffโs
27 individual claim because [relief for] the named plaintiff fails to satisfy the
28 demands of the class.โ)

3 Plaintiffs are correct that the concept of presumed damages has an ancient
4 pedigree, but incorrect in concluding that its use is justified in class actions for
5 ยง 1983 claims.  The common law drew a distinction between the โgeneral
6 damagesโ and the โspecial damagesโ caused by a legal wrong.  See, e.g.,
7 Vanderslice v. Newton, 4 N.Y. 130, 132 (1850).  โThose which necessarily result
8 from the injury are termed general damages,โ in contrast to special damages,
9 which โare the natural, although not the necessary result of the injury.โ  Id. 
10 Because general damages were presumed to result from the legal wrong, they did
11 not need to be โspeciallyโ pleaded or proved.  Hogue-Kellogg Co. v. Baker, 47
12 Cal. App. 247, 250-51 (1920).  General damages were common in defamation
13 actions, where it was held that โa plaintiff is entitled to general damages as
14 compensation for those injuries which the law presumes must naturally and
15 necessarily result from [a libelous] publication.โ  New York Evening Post Co. v.
16 Chaloner, 265 F. 204, 220 (2d Cir. 1920).
17 More recently, however, the Supreme Court labeled the common law of
18 defamation โan oddity of tort law, for it allows recovery of purportedly
19 compensatory damages without evidence of actual loss.โ  Gertz v. Robert Welch,
20 Inc., 418 U.S. 345, 349 (1974).  The Court has neither ratified nor rejected the
21 concept of presumed damages in ยง 1983 actions, but has placed limits on their
22 use.7  In Carey v. Piphus, the Court considered whether plaintiffs could recover
